_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Chief Ethanol Fuels, Inc. (Chief Ethanol) actively pursues a safe and healthy workplace in accordance with our corporate Safety and Health policies.  Management is actively involved with employees in establishing and maintaining an effective safety and health program.  Managers participate with employees in ongoing safety and health program activities, including:

1) Promoting safety and health through active personal example and committee participation;

2) Providing safety and health education and training for employees, supervisors and managers; and

3) Reviewing, updating and enforcing workplace safety and health rules.



Facility Description

Chief Ethanol, located in Hastings, Nebraska, was constructed in 1984 to produce grain derived denatured ethanol for motor fuel while providing animal feed from the remaining distiller's grains.  Major expansions completed in 1993, 1999, 2006, & 2008 have resulted in the plant having the capacity to produce approximately 80 Mmgal per year of denatured fuel grade ethanol. During 2020 the facility started producing industrial ethanol for hand sanitizer as a response to the COVID-19 national pandemic in addition to fuel ethanol.   

Ethanol is produced by a fermentation process using corn or milo.  Chief Ethanol processes approximately 80,000 bushels of grain per day.  In addition to ethanol production, the plant produces up to 600,000 tons per year of distiller's grains (both wet and dry) that is used for an animal feed.  Natural gasoline is used to denature the fuel ethanol produced and is stored at the plant in a 30,000 gallon above ground steel storage tank within a 4.5 ft high diked secondary containment area.  



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response

Chief Ethanol follows the Process Safety Management OSHA standard and incorporates the PSM elements for the ethanol distillation, storage, and loading process.  Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies are included in the site's SPCC,

Storm Water Pollution Prevention, and Emergency Action plans.  Emergency response activities are coordinated with the local emergency responders and the Adams County Local Emergency Planning Committee.  Outside contractors provide mechanical integrity and leak testing services on a routine basis. The plant is operated 24/7 so has personnel monitoring the system and performing daily inspections of the plant equipment.  Security is provided through security cameras, fencing, personnel, and other means.   



5 year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases that have caused injury or offsite consequences in the past five years. 

 

Summary of Changes Occurred or Planned Changes to Improve Safety

No significant changes were made that impact the RMP.  Chief Ethanol will continue to survey the employees regularly to find ways to improve safety and determine future changes.
